Prompt: What kind of food is Vancouver known for?
Full_Prompt: What kind of food is Vancouver known for? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Vancouver’s food scene is shaped by its Pacific Coast location, large Asian population, and access to fresh local ingredients. Here are the main things it’s especially known for, with sources you can check:

---

### 1. Sushi & Japanese Food  
Vancouver is often cited as having some of the best and most affordable sushi in North America, thanks to its Pacific seafood and large Japanese community.

- Common specialties:  
  - Salmon and tuna nigiri  
  - Local spot prawns (in season)  
  - “BC roll” (usually salmon skin, cucumber, sauce) – a local invention  
- Neighborhoods: Downtown, West End, Kitsilano, and Richmond (just south of Vancouver) are packed with sushi spots.

**Sources:**
- Tourism Vancouver (Destination Vancouver) – “Sushi in Vancouver”:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/type/sushi/
- Vancouver Is Awesome – “Why Vancouver is obsessed with sushi”:  
  https://www.vancouverisawesome.com/food-and-drink/vancouver-sushi-obsessed-1939491  

---

### 2. Pacific Northwest Seafood  
Vancouver is known for fresh, local seafood from the Pacific Ocean and nearby rivers.

- Signature items:  
  - Wild Pacific salmon (grilled, smoked, or in chowders)  
  - Halibut and cod (often in fish & chips)  
  - Dungeness crab  
  - BC spot prawns (a big seasonal delicacy, usually May–June)  
  - Oysters from BC waters

**Sources:**
- Destination BC – “Seafood in British Columbia”:  
  https://www.hellobc.com/stories/seafood-in-british-columbia/  
- Destination Vancouver – “Seafood Restaurants in Vancouver”:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/type/seafood/

---

### 3. Chinese & Pan-Asian Cuisine (especially in Richmond)  
Metro Vancouver, particularly Richmond, is famous for top-tier Chinese food and a wide range of Asian cuisines (Hong Kong, Taiwanese, Shanghainese, Sichuan, etc.).

- Known for:  
  - Dim sum  
  - Cantonese seafood banquets  
  - Taiwanese bubble tea and snacks  
  - Regional Chinese cuisines (Sichuan, Shanghainese, etc.)

**Sources:**
- The New York Times – “In Richmond, B.C., Asian Food Beyond Compare”:  
  https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/09/travel/richmond-british-columbia-asian-food.html  
- Tourism Richmond – “Food & Drink”:  
  https://www.visitrichmondbc.com/restaurants/

---

### 4. Indigenous (First Nations)–Inspired Cuisine  
There’s growing recognition of Indigenous ingredients and cooking traditions from the First Nations of the Pacific Northwest.

- Typical elements:  
  - Cedar-plank salmon  
  - Bannock (fried or baked bread)  
  - Game meats (elk, venison)  
  - Foraged ingredients (berries, seaweed, wild herbs)

**Sources:**
- Destination BC – “Indigenous Culinary Experiences in BC”:  
  https://www.hellobc.com/stories/indigenous-culinary-experiences-in-bc/  
- Indigenous Tourism BC – Food & Drink:  
  https://www.indigenousbc.com/things-to-do/food-drink

---

### 5. Farm-to-Table & Local, Seasonal Cuisine  
Vancouver is known for “West Coast” or “Pacific Northwest” cuisine: seasonal, local, and often vegetable-forward.

- Features:  
  - Local produce from the Fraser Valley and Okanagan  
  - Craft beer, BC wines, and cider pairings  
  - Menus that change with the seasons

**Sources:**
- Destination Vancouver – “Farm-to-Table Dining”:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/farm-to-table/  
- Tourism Vancouver – “West Coast Cuisine”:  
  (archived/overview style) https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/

---

### 6. Food Trucks & Casual Street Food  
Vancouver has a strong food truck scene, often focused on fusion and local ingredients.

- Well-known styles:  
  - Japanese-Mexican fusion (e.g., sushi burritos, “Japadog”-style hot dogs)  
  - Gourmet grilled cheese, tacos, and burgers  
  - Korean, Filipino, and other Asian street foods

**Sources:**
- Street Food Vancouver (official city food truck map):  
  https://streetfoodvancouver.com/  
- Destination Vancouver – “Food Trucks in Vancouver”:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/type/food-trucks/

---

### 7. Coffee, Craft Beer, and BC Wine  
While not “food” per se, Vancouver is also known for:

- Third-wave coffee shops  
- A dense craft beer scene (East Van “Yeast Van” area especially)  
- Proximity to BC wine regions (Okanagan, Fraser Valley)

**Sources:**
- Vancouver’s North Shore Tourism – “Craft Beer & Breweries”:  
  https://vancouversnorthshore.com/things-to-do/beer-wine-spirits/  
- Destination Vancouver – “Coffee Shops”:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/type/cafes-coffee-shops/

---

If you tell me what you like to eat (e.g., sushi, dim sum, seafood, vegetarian), I can suggest specific Vancouver dishes or neighborhoods that match your tastes, and how they compare to what you’re used to in San Francisco.

Prompt: What kind of food is Vancouver known for?
Full_Prompt: What kind of food is Vancouver known for? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Vancouver’s food scene is shaped by its Pacific Coast location, large Asian population, and access to fresh local ingredients. Here are the main things it’s especially known for, with sources you can check:

---

### 1. Sushi & Japanese Food  
Vancouver is often cited as having some of the best and most affordable sushi in North America, thanks to its Pacific seafood and large Japanese community.

- Common specialties:  
  - Salmon and tuna nigiri  
  - Local spot prawns (in season)  
  - “BC roll” (usually salmon skin, cucumber, sauce) – a local invention  
- Neighborhoods: Downtown, West End, Kitsilano, and Richmond (just south of Vancouver) are packed with sushi spots.

**Sources:**
- Tourism Vancouver (Destination Vancouver) – “Sushi in Vancouver”:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/type/sushi/
- Vancouver Is Awesome – “Why Vancouver is obsessed with sushi”:  
  https://www.vancouverisawesome.com/food-and-drink/vancouver-sushi-obsessed-1939491  

---

### 2. Pacific Northwest Seafood  
Vancouver is known for fresh, local seafood from the Pacific Ocean and nearby rivers.

- Signature items:  
  - Wild Pacific salmon (grilled, smoked, or in chowders)  
  - Halibut and cod (often in fish & chips)  
  - Dungeness crab  
  - BC spot prawns (a big seasonal delicacy, usually May–June)  
  - Oysters from BC waters

**Sources:**
- Destination BC – “Seafood in British Columbia”:  
  https://www.hellobc.com/stories/seafood-in-british-columbia/  
- Destination Vancouver – “Seafood Restaurants in Vancouver”:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/type/seafood/

---

### 3. Chinese & Pan-Asian Cuisine (especially in Richmond)  
Metro Vancouver, particularly Richmond, is famous for top-tier Chinese food and a wide range of Asian cuisines (Hong Kong, Taiwanese, Shanghainese, Sichuan, etc.).

- Known for:  
  - Dim sum  
  - Cantonese seafood banquets  
  - Taiwanese bubble tea and snacks  
  - Regional Chinese cuisines (Sichuan, Shanghainese, etc.)

**Sources:**
- The New York Times – “In Richmond, B.C., Asian Food Beyond Compare”:  
  https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/09/travel/richmond-british-columbia-asian-food.html  
- Tourism Richmond – “Food & Drink”:  
  https://www.visitrichmondbc.com/restaurants/

---

### 4. Indigenous (First Nations)–Inspired Cuisine  
There’s growing recognition of Indigenous ingredients and cooking traditions from the First Nations of the Pacific Northwest.

- Typical elements:  
  - Cedar-plank salmon  
  - Bannock (fried or baked bread)  
  - Game meats (elk, venison)  
  - Foraged ingredients (berries, seaweed, wild herbs)

**Sources:**
- Destination BC – “Indigenous Culinary Experiences in BC”:  
  https://www.hellobc.com/stories/indigenous-culinary-experiences-in-bc/  
- Indigenous Tourism BC – Food & Drink:  
  https://www.indigenousbc.com/things-to-do/food-drink

---

### 5. Farm-to-Table & Local, Seasonal Cuisine  
Vancouver is known for “West Coast” or “Pacific Northwest” cuisine: seasonal, local, and often vegetable-forward.

- Features:  
  - Local produce from the Fraser Valley and Okanagan  
  - Craft beer, BC wines, and cider pairings  
  - Menus that change with the seasons

**Sources:**
- Destination Vancouver – “Farm-to-Table Dining”:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/farm-to-table/  
- Tourism Vancouver – “West Coast Cuisine”:  
  (archived/overview style) https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/

---

### 6. Food Trucks & Casual Street Food  
Vancouver has a strong food truck scene, often focused on fusion and local ingredients.

- Well-known styles:  
  - Japanese-Mexican fusion (e.g., sushi burritos, “Japadog”-style hot dogs)  
  - Gourmet grilled cheese, tacos, and burgers  
  - Korean, Filipino, and other Asian street foods

**Sources:**
- Street Food Vancouver (official city food truck map):  
  https://streetfoodvancouver.com/  
- Destination Vancouver – “Food Trucks in Vancouver”:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/type/food-trucks/

---

- A dense craft beer scene (East Van “Yeast Van” area especially)  
- Proximity to BC wine regions (Okanagan, Fraser Valley)

Prompt: What kind of food is Vancouver known for?
Full_Prompt: What kind of food is Vancouver known for? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Vancouver’s food reputation is shaped by its Pacific coastal location, multicultural population, and strong local/seasonal focus. Key things it’s known for:

1. **Pacific Northwest Seafood (especially Salmon & Halibut)**  
   - Wild Pacific salmon (grilled, smoked, candied, in chowders, or on cedar planks)  
   - Halibut, sablefish (black cod), spot prawns in season (May–June)  
   - Often prepared simply to highlight freshness, or in West Coast fusion dishes  
   **Sources:**  
   - Destination Vancouver – “Seafood in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/what-to-eat/seafood/  
   - Tourism Vancouver Island (for regional context on Pacific seafood):  
     https://www.tourismvi.ca/blog/pacific-seafood-guide  

2. **Sushi & Japanese Food**  
   - Vancouver is frequently cited as having some of the best and most affordable sushi in North America, thanks to its large Japanese community and access to fresh fish.  
   - You’ll find everything from cheap “BC rolls” (with barbecued salmon skin) to high‑end omakase.  
   **Sources:**  
   - BBC Travel – “Why Vancouver is North America’s sushi capital”:  
     https://www.bbc.com/travel/article/20190324-why-vancouver-is-north-americas-sushi-capital  
   - Destination Vancouver – “Japanese Restaurants in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/cuisine/japanese/  

3. **Asian Cuisine & Fusion (Chinese, Korean, Southeast Asian)**  
   - Large Chinese, Hong Kong, Taiwanese, Korean, and Southeast Asian communities mean excellent dim sum, hot pot, bubble tea, Korean BBQ, pho, and more.  
   - Nearby Richmond (part of Metro Vancouver) is especially famous for Chinese food and Asian night markets.  
   **Sources:**  
   - The New York Times – “In Richmond, B.C., Asian Food Is the Main Attraction”:  
     https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/20/travel/richmond-british-columbia-asian-food.html  
   - Destination Vancouver – “Asian Cuisine in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/cuisine/asian/  

4. **West Coast / Farm‑to‑Table Cuisine**  
   - Seasonal, local ingredients: BC produce, foraged mushrooms, local cheeses, and sustainable seafood.  
   - Often called “Pacific Northwest” or “West Coast” cuisine, with light, fresh preparations and global influences.  
   **Sources:**  
   - Destination BC – “Pacific Northwest Cuisine”:  
     https://www.hellobc.com/stories/pacific-northwest-cuisine-in-british-columbia/  
   - Destination Vancouver – “What to Eat in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/what-to-eat/  

5. **Indigenous‑Inspired Dishes (Emerging but Important)**  
   - Increasing recognition of First Nations ingredients and techniques: salmon, bannock, game meats, berries, seaweed.  
   - Some restaurants and food tours highlight Indigenous‑inspired cuisine.  
   **Sources:**  
   - Indigenous Tourism BC – “Indigenous Culinary Experiences”:  
     https://www.indigenousbc.com/things-to-do/culinary  
   - Destination Vancouver – “Indigenous Experiences in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/indigenous/  

6. **Food Trucks & Casual Street Food**  
   - Known for creative food trucks: Japadog (Japanese‑style hot dogs), taco trucks, fusion burgers, and more.  
   - Japadog in particular has become a bit of a Vancouver icon.  
   **Sources:**  
   - Japadog official site: https://www.japadog.com/  
   - Destination Vancouver – “Food Trucks in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/what-to-eat/food-trucks/  

7. **Craft Beer & Coffee Culture (Not food, but part of the scene)**  
   - Strong craft beer scene with many microbreweries in East Van and beyond.  
   - Third‑wave coffee shops are common, with local roasters and café culture.  
   **Sources:**  
   - Vancouver’s North Shore Tourism – “Vancouver’s Craft Beer Scene”:  
     https://vancouversnorthshore.com/things-to-do/craft-beer/  
   - Destination Vancouver – “Coffee Shops in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/what-to-eat/coffee/

Prompt: What kind of food is Vancouver known for?
Full_Prompt: What kind of food is Vancouver known for? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Vancouver’s food reputation is shaped by its Pacific coastal location, multicultural population, and strong local/seasonal focus. Key things it’s known for:

1. **Pacific Northwest Seafood (especially Salmon & Halibut)**  
   - Wild Pacific salmon (grilled, smoked, candied, in chowders, or on cedar planks)  
   - Halibut, sablefish (black cod), spot prawns in season (May–June)  
   - Often prepared simply to highlight freshness, or in West Coast fusion dishes  
   **Sources:**  
   - Destination Vancouver – “Seafood in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/what-to-eat/seafood/  
   - Tourism Vancouver Island (for regional context on Pacific seafood):  
     https://www.tourismvi.ca/blog/pacific-seafood-guide  

2. **Sushi & Japanese Food**  
   - Vancouver is frequently cited as having some of the best and most affordable sushi in North America, thanks to its large Japanese community and access to fresh fish.  
   - You’ll find everything from cheap “BC rolls” (with barbecued salmon skin) to high‑end omakase.  
   **Sources:**  
   - BBC Travel – “Why Vancouver is North America’s sushi capital”:  
     https://www.bbc.com/travel/article/20190324-why-vancouver-is-north-americas-sushi-capital  
   - Destination Vancouver – “Japanese Restaurants in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/cuisine/japanese/  

3. **Asian Cuisine & Fusion (Chinese, Korean, Southeast Asian)**  
   - Large Chinese, Hong Kong, Taiwanese, Korean, and Southeast Asian communities mean excellent dim sum, hot pot, bubble tea, Korean BBQ, pho, and more.  
   - Nearby Richmond (part of Metro Vancouver) is especially famous for Chinese food and Asian night markets.  
   **Sources:**  
   - The New York Times – “In Richmond, B.C., Asian Food Is the Main Attraction”:  
     https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/20/travel/richmond-british-columbia-asian-food.html  
   - Destination Vancouver – “Asian Cuisine in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/cuisine/asian/  

4. **West Coast / Farm‑to‑Table Cuisine**  
   - Seasonal, local ingredients: BC produce, foraged mushrooms, local cheeses, and sustainable seafood.  
   - Often called “Pacific Northwest” or “West Coast” cuisine, with light, fresh preparations and global influences.  
   **Sources:**  
   - Destination BC – “Pacific Northwest Cuisine”:  
     https://www.hellobc.com/stories/pacific-northwest-cuisine-in-british-columbia/  
   - Destination Vancouver – “What to Eat in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/what-to-eat/  

5. **Indigenous‑Inspired Dishes (Emerging but Important)**  
   - Increasing recognition of First Nations ingredients and techniques: salmon, bannock, game meats, berries, seaweed.  
   - Some restaurants and food tours highlight Indigenous‑inspired cuisine.  
   **Sources:**  
   - Indigenous Tourism BC – “Indigenous Culinary Experiences”:  
     https://www.indigenousbc.com/things-to-do/culinary  
   - Destination Vancouver – “Indigenous Experiences in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/indigenous/  

6. **Food Trucks & Casual Street Food**  
   - Known for creative food trucks: Japadog (Japanese‑style hot dogs), taco trucks, fusion burgers, and more.  
   - Japadog in particular has become a bit of a Vancouver icon.  
   **Sources:**  
   - Japadog official site: https://www.japadog.com/  
   - Destination Vancouver – “Food Trucks in Vancouver”:  
     https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/what-to-eat/food-trucks/  

7. **Craft Beer & Coffee Culture (Not food, but part of the scene)**  
   - Strong craft beer scene with many microbreweries in East Van and beyond.  
   - Third‑wave coffee shops are common, with local roasters and café culture.  
   **Sources:**
